newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sony says still negotiating JSkyB deal.
newsitem.headline: Sony says still negotiating JSkyB deal.

text.p: A Sony Corp spokeswoman on Thursday denied a Japanese media report that the company could sign a contract as early as next week to take a 25 to 30 percent stake in Japan Sky Broadcasting Co, or JSkyB.

Japan's Kyodo news agency reported on Thursday, quoting unidentified informed sources, that Sony had decided in principle to acquire a 25 to 30 percent stake in JSkyB, which is currently a partnership between Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Japanese publishing firm Softbank Corp.
Kyodo said a deal would be signed as early as next week in New York.

"There is no change in our position that we are still negotiating the issue... We are not in a position now to say that a contract is likely as early as next week, nor have we decided an acquisition ratio," the Sony spokeswoman said.
"There are no such prospects now," she added.
Last week, Sony president Nobuyuki Idei told Reuters that his company was seeking an active management role in the satellite TV alliance, which will bring Sony lucrative new business opportunities.
Idei said negotiations on its investments in JSkyB were continuing and did not comment on details, but added: "We have no intention of being a silent partner."
Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp, has basically agreed to Sony having an active management role in JSkyB, Idei said in the interview with Reuters.
The 20 billion yen venture will launch test broadcasting in Japan in April and a full 100-channel service early next year.

Idei said broadcasting will provide Sony with effective distribution channels and allow the group to make coherent and strategic investments in content and hardware businesses, such as set-top boxes and base stations.
Kyodo reported that the deal would be signed by Idei, Murdoch and Softbank chairman Masayoshi Son.
